H0.text: Both the wasp parasite and the insect larva host benefit from the relationship in which the wasp lays its eggs inside the larva.

H1.text: Both the parasite and the host are harmed is the relationship between the parasite and the host when a species of wasp lays its eggs in the larva of another insect.

H2.text: The parasite benefits and the host is harmed when a wasp lays its eggs in the larva of another insect.

H3.text: The parasite is harmed and the host benefits is the relationship between the wasp that lays its eggs in the larva of another insect and that larva.

A4.text: Parasitoids are insects which sooner or later kill their hosts.

A5.text: Parasites increase their own fitness by exploiting hosts for resources necessary for their survival, in particular by feeding on them and by using intermediate (secondary) hosts to assist in their transmission from one definitive (primary) host to another.
